thread.title: Tom Jurich: No plans for Rick Pitino to step down as Louisville basketball coach
thread.title_full: Tom Jurich: No plans for Rick Pitino to step down as Louisville basketball coach

title: Tom Jurich: No plans for Rick Pitino to step down as Louisville basketball coach
text:
VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL Louisville under fire after sex scandal | 01:15 USA TODAY Sports' Scott Gleeson explains what's next at Louisville following a reported sex scandal involving Cardinals players and recruits.
1 of 7 VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL Pitino talks escort allegations at Cards Luncheon | 05:15 Louisville basketball coach Rick Pitino took time to address the recent paid escort allegations made by Katina Powell in her new book "Breaking Cardinal Rules" during Cards annual luncheon event. Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
2 of 7 VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL AP: Reaction to Louisville Investigation | 02:02 The AP’s Paul Newberry and CineSport's Jacob Wilkins discuss the shocking allegations made against Louisville and talk about where the university and the NCAA go from here with the investigation.
3 of 7 VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL Rick Pitino: 'The truth will come out' | 05:30 "I base things on the truth," Rick Pitino said after being asked about his mindset regarding sex allegations of recruits in a book recently published. Matt Stone, The Courier-Journal
4 of 7 VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL Video | Pitino addresses media about recent allegations | 18:52 Louisville coach Rick Pitino says he was heartbroken when he heard the allegations that a former staff memeber purchased escorts for players/recruits.
5 of 7 VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL Video | Jeff Greer discusses the UofL book scandal | 08:28 The C-J's Jeff Greer and Chris White discuss the Katina Powell book, head coach Rick Pitino's reaction to it and what it means for basketball recruiting. Video by Jeff Faughender
6 of 7 VIDEOS | LOUISVILLE BASKETBALL KATINA POWELL SCANDAL Video | Pitino's full remarks 2015 Tip-Off Luncheon | 18:06 These are Rick Pitino's complete remarks to boosters at the 2015 Louisville basketball Tip Off Luncheon. Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
7 of 7 Last Video Next Video Louisville under fire after sex scandal Pitino talks escort allegations at Cards Luncheon AP: Reaction to Louisville Investigation Rick Pitino: 'The truth will come out' Video | Pitino addresses media about recent allegations Video | Jeff Greer discusses the UofL book scandal Video | Pitino's full remarks 2015 Tip-Off Luncheon U of L AD Tom Jurich (Photo: C-J FILE)
45 CONNECT 24 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Louisville athletic director Tom Jurich backed basketball coach Rick Pitino on Tuesday in the wake of ESPN's report on a book filled with allegations against Pitino's program.
"He has no plans to step down," Jurich said through U of L spokesman Kenny Klein. "He has a long-term contract. He absolutely did not know anything about these allegations."
The ESPN report corroborated parts of self-described escort Katina Powell's book, "Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen," citing five unnamed former players or recruits who said there were stripper parties in the team's dormitory on campus. One former U of L player told ESPN that he had sex with one of the escorts, and that former U of L staffer Andre McGee paid for it. ESPN's "Outside the Lines" also said it independently confirmed Powell's cellphone contacts with McGee.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Ex-U of L recruit: 'Like I was in a strip club'
ESPN's report aired on "Good Morning America" and "SportsCenter" on Tuesday morning and ran for a full hour on "Outside the Lines" on Tuesday afternoon.
Pitino told The Courier-Journal that he was "devastated" and "disappointed" by the report.
Jurich offered a statement supporting Pitino on Tuesday afternoon through a spokesman, making the second time in recent weeks that either Pitino or Jurich has commented on the coach's future.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
'Long process' awaits U of L hoops and NCAA
Pitino was irked by a statement from U of L president James Ramsey two weeks ago that only mentioned supporting Jurich. On a local radio show, Pitino said resigning would be the "cowardly" route to take.
"I don't know what resigning would accomplish," Pitino said. "I think that's the cowardly way out. ... What does it do for the program if the head coach just runs away?"
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Watch the Katina Powell interview
Get the CJ’s free UofL CardsHQ newsletter
45 CONNECT 24 TWEET LINKEDIN 1
